message: Otherwise, very interesting resource. Bookmarked. :)
Micrypt - you are right! http://www.scala-lang.org/node/5130 confirms it. Updated http://lineofthought.com/sites/foursquare

It's basically a way to share the technology behind a website, or find out more about which sites are using a specific tool. As a developer it's something that I was looking for a while back, but didn't exist so decided to build it. :)
Any feedback on the idea, design or anything else is very much appreciated. It's still in the early stages and a bit rough around the edges, but getting there.

that actually a really cool idea and concept, it would be even cooler (i know it is at the beginning stages) if you give the names of the CTO's of the companys like you can use crunchpad and also if you had like the CTO's also verify that is the technology on the site, like a seal of this is true, like verifying on twitter just an idea but this cool
@adamfortuna well if you get one CTO *cough* @ericflo *cough* others would follow it only takes one
Here's a link for more information on the site: http://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=2456393
Here's an example: Tools used to build Convore http://lineofthought.com/sites/convore

Verification is definitely going to be a tough task. Been trying to think of good ways to do it, but I think company verification is going to be the only surefire way. Thanks for the feedback! Right now you can claim a site, then lock it from being edited by other people, but we don't show publicly that the site has been claimed by a site owner. Probably be good to do some kind of special distinction between tools added by everyone else, and tools verified by the site owner.
@adamfortuna http://lineofthought.com/sites/foursquare is inaccurate. Foursquare's powered by the Lift framework. http://liftweb.net

@NoLongerAMember Revenue is still a ways off. I'm thinking the lowest hanging fruit would be job postings. Say you're looking at a site, you cold see job postings at that site. Of if you're looking into a specific tool, you could see some jobs using that tool. Beyond that though, we'll see. :)

Ok, I think that's great. I am always curious about how a site was actually built so I am a fan of http://lineofthought.com. A few thoughts: How do verify accuracy? In addition to satisfying my curiosity, what else could I do at this site? And how do you turn this idea into revenue?  Thanks for a cool product.
@italiano40 haha true. :) I think once a few sites start doing it, a lot could potentially follow.
Really nice site, like the UI simple and very useable - good idea too
@shutton thanks! Stripped out so many "this would be cool..." features down, and think it really helped focus the site.

@NoLongerAMember Thanks! Right now we are not verifying accuracy. Logged in users can remove a tool used on a site, or add it back in (kind of like a wiki - where you can view past edits). Verification is going to be a huge part later on, but for now it's pretty much open.
Cool, just updated the Convore entry a bit, thanks for setting this up @adamfortuna!
@ericflo Awesome, thanks! Your descriptive blog posts made it a easy to get some sample info for Convore. http://lineofthought.com/sites/convore
Maybe if you could somehow build a community or something...  Or maybe build widgets for embedding elsewhere...
@adamfortuna great work. I probably will add a few sites of mine later on.

I think this is pretty cool, but I feel like it should be part of something bigger.  Like maybe a feature on StackOverflow.  As-is I think I'm going to bookmark this page, stick it in my "cool shit to look at at some point" folder, and then never look at it again.

@jca Later on I'm thinking about adding a Q&A section for sites. So if a site owner enables it, people can ask questions so a verified owner of the site about anything, then the owner could moderate/answer. The other idea is tightly integrated job postings - both the paid kinds and the "i'm looking for a cofounder/volunteer to help out with this site/tool" kind of posts. Still not sure what the next step will be to make it more useful though.

@jca yeah, know what you mean. It's cool, but it lacks stickiness and long lasting usefulness. I like the idea of widgets for embedding. I see if as a source for people to link to on what their site uses (like on their about page for example).

I really like this idea, and even moreso, your implementation. Clean, simple, informative. I was using the builtwith chrome browser extension, but I like this a bit more. (although, consider a browser extension too, as that's very handy!) Nice work!
Awesome idea. Bookmarked.
and Q&A for sites would be really good
This is really cool! I like.
great!

@adamfortuna FYI, despite my expectation I did end up coming back to the site.  I needed a tool for full-text search and remembered seeing "sphinx" on your site as a popular tool.  I couldn't remember the name of the tool though, so that's why I came back to check.  Maybe you could focus on that use case:  "What's the best tool for X?"
Great idea, I have spent time searching for this type of information in the past, will definitely use as a resource
@jimisir  @jescarter @NARKOZ Thanks! Still a work in progress, but glad it's appealing to some off the bat.

@jca Ahh, that's a real good point. We have a category system for tools, so I might be able to expand on that for answers to at least some kinds of questions. If we can get that right, I can see it being a very useful tool. Thanks for the advice. :)

@geoffclapp Thanks! I'm thinking about starting out with a bookmarklet that opens a popup with the tools currently added for the site you're on, and moving from there into browser extensions. We'll always be in a different boat (at least in the foreseeable future) than builtwith though, as they scrub the page and find everything, while we're relying on user entered info. Might change eventually tough, but thanks for the feedback!
That's pretty cool!  There's a site that analyzes what it can see over http and tells you what technologies it thinks the site is using that reminds me of this one... anyone know that one?
idk if someone said this already but bookmarklet?  "click to see the technologies used on this site"

added my startup http://lineofthought.com/sites/15secondsme

@adamfortuna This is a great site...definitely lacking with search functionality but nonetheless nice work.  How long did it take you to make?  I remember coming across another site that did something similar but can't find it now.

@akuril Thanks! And thanks for the comment about search, definitely think it's important to add that back in. It took a little over a month to make. I had a few weeks off between jobs, and spent a lot of that time to work through this idea, in addition to some part time while employed.

It would be nice to have a source or reference for each technology, e.g. with 4sq the scala section could have a "source" link to http://www.scala-lang.org/node/5130. (Similar to Wikipedia's "references" section).
